div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,137] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, MARCH 2, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Pagnon's Hotels.
div.p: Catarct Hotel, Assouan.

This most popular hotel on the Upper Nile has recently been enlarged by the addition of 65 rooms and accomodates guests. Great dining hall, lifts, tennis court and garden. On the south side overlooking the river. Billard room and bar., electric light throughout. Anglican Church within a few minutes of the Hotel grounds.

Grand Hotel, Assouan.-Under the same management. Beautifully situated on river. Accommodates 90 guests. Moderate terms. Entirely rebuilt since the fire, and fitted throughout in the most modern style. Beuatiful terrace overlooking river. Electric light throughout.

div.head: Grand Hotel, Khartoum
div.p: Standing in a magnificient position in its own grounds on the high banks on the Blue Nile.

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday was a fine day. In the morning the wind blew-lightly from the S. and in the middle of the day it was inclined to be warm but at the end of the day the wind died away into a calm, and at 7 p.m. freshened again from the North, i.e. in an opposite direction. There was a slight haze throughout the night and the day opens calm dull, and cloudly. Barometer steady.

TUESDAY, MARCH 2, 1905.

div.head: It is Peace?
div.p: The London newspapers appear to have received with absolute good faith the proposals set forward by Reuter’s correspondent at St. Petersburg as the terms on which Russia seeks or would consent to a cessation of hostilities. Under the circumstances these terms are perhaps more reasonable than might have been expected though almost certainly they are not the terms which Japan will now

div.head: Sunlight
div.p: When SUNLIGHT SOAP is in the tub,
You needn't boil, nor toil, nor scrub; just try it in the SUNLIGHT Way,

Soap

accept. We must, of course, regard these “terms” merely as a tentative document designed to test opinion both in Japan and other countries. It is by no means clear as yet that that peace is, an immediate probability. What may be said is given a sweet reasonableness on the part of the Tsar and his advisers, it is in sight. And that is something on which a world horrified by the immensity of slaughter will sincerely congratulate itself and the combatants.

The terms suggested obviously are less than a victorious Japan will demand. What has been won by the sword is to be “ceded” to Japan, Vladivostok is to have the “open door”—a concession that has by now lost whatever glamour was once attached to it—the Eastern Chinese railway is to be placed under a neutral international administration, and Mari-churia,as far north as Harbin, is to be restored to China. No mention is made of any indemnity save as a difficulty not thought to be insuperable. No mention at all is made of the Russian ships interned in neutral harbours, and another big battle has evidently been risked within the last few days.

Already, we imagine, Japan, with uninter rupted victory behind her, will consent to no peace that is not permanent and completely satisfactory. Her demands no doubt have grown with the progress of the war. This has been to her a life and death struggle which she has no intention of abandoning for the moment that it may be renewed when Russia has recovered, for internal and external purposes. She is strong enough and determined enough to impose her own will, and to leave her task unfinished would be too dear a price to pay even for the blessings of peace. These considerations have to be understood by the Government of Russia—the people only want the war to end—before their troubles abroad can he ended, and all energies devoted to the troubles at home. Meanwhile it is for us to welcome the signs of a reasonable frame of mind and to do all in our power to further the cause of peace that can be done in consonance with our obligations to our ally, with our own vital interests, and with those eternal principles of justice for which Japan drew the sword.

British Chamber of Commerce.—We would call the attention of persons interested in Egyptian trade to the work of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt, whose office in Alexandria gives information as to standings, trade, &c., to its members, and whose monthly publication reviews our commerce. The annual subscription is £1 and all British traders should become members. Our London office, 36, New Broad-street E.C., acts as London agency to the Chamber.

div.head: ON THE SHA-HO.
div.p: SHARP FIGHTING REPORTED
London, March 1. Russian and Japanese telegrams report sharp fighting in the vicinity of the Sha-Ho railway bridge. Both sides claim an advantage. (R.)
POLAND.
MARTIAL LAW PROCLAIMED.
Warsaw, March 1. Martial law has been proclaimed throughout Poland.
The train service is improving generally. (Reuter.)
JAPAN’S FINANCES.
LITTLE DISTURBED BY THE WAR.
Tokio, March 1. At a meeting of bankers and financiers here, it was announced that the domestic loan would be doubly subscribed.
M. Okuma, addressing the meeting, said he anticipated there would be little disturbance as regards the finance of the country in consequence of the war, despite the enormous expenditure. (Reuter.)
GENERAL STOESSEL.
HERO OF THE HOUR IN RUSSIA.

Moscow, March 1. General Stoessel is the hero of the hour. His hotel is besieged by crowds. He lunched yesterday with the widow of the Grand Duke Sergius. Afterwards, replying to the welcome given to him by a deputation from the Municipality, he declared that it was his duty to surrender Port Arthur in order to avoid a massacre, as the Japanese had captured all the important forts. The General started for St. Petersburg in the evening. (Reuter.)
St. Petersburg, March 1. The arrival of General Stoessel has been hailed with acclamations. (Havas.
THE SUGAR CONVENTION
AMENDMENT IN THE HOUSE.

London, March 1. House of Commons.—An amendment to the Address, urging the denunciation of the Sugar Convention in view of its prejudicial effect on Great Britain, was rejected by 275 to 211 votes. (Reuter.)
YEMEN INSURRECTION.
FIERCE FIGHTING.
Jeddah, March 1. The insurgents have defeated the troops in Yemen. There has been fierce fighting round Saana during the last five days. The result is unknown. (Reuter.)
LORD MILNER’S SUCCESSOR.
LORD SELBORNE APPOINTED.
London, March 1. Lord Selborne has been appointed to succeed Lord Milner, who will leave South Africa at the end of March. (Reuter.)
MIXED TRIBUNALS IN EGYPT.
EXTENSION OF POWERS.
Paris, March 1 M. Délcassé has had signed the approbation of the prolongation by H.H. the Khedive of the powers of the Mixed Tribunals for another quinquennial period. (Havas

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: A Council of Ministers will be held next Monday at Abdeen Palace under the presidency of H.H. the Khedive.
The Cairo Tramway Company are about to introduce a new model of car on their lines, comprise first and second class compartments.
The Charity Bazaar and lottery organised by Mme. de la Boulinière has been a great financial success, the gross receipts amounting to L.E. 1,556.74.
Khartoum Garrison.—Last night, a detachment of the 2nd Battalion Rifle Brigade, numbering three officers and 91 N.C.O.’s and men, left Cairo for Khartoum.
Agriculturists’ Union. — The February Bulletin of the Union Syndicale des Agriculteurs d’Egypte contains articles on “Water Lifting,’’ “Rural Legislation,” etc., etc.
Raoul Pugno’s Recital.—The second concert to be given at Alexandria by M. Raoul Pugno, the great French pianist, will take place at the New Khédivial Hotel this evening.
Sales of Land.—On Tuesday several plots of land Situated at Ghezireh were sold by public auction at the Cairo Gouvernorat. A figure of P.T. 93 per square metre was reached.

“The Cyprus Journal” for February is an unusually interesting number and contains a number of excellent contributions dealing mainly with the agriculture and commerce of the island, as well as with its archæology.

Concert.—M. Constantin Nicolaou, of the “Scala” at Milan, a Greek singer of repute, is giving a concert at the New Khedivial Hotel, Alexandria, on Friday, 10th inst., for which tickets may be had at Hackh’s music-store.

New Doctors.—The Ministry of the Interior has authorised Doctors Faraci Giuseppe and Démosthène C. Hadzi Anagnostou, Mr. Pierre Loghothety, pharmacist, and Mrs. Marie N. Bretarou, midwife, to follow their professions in Egypt.

Y. W. C. A.—H.R.H. the Duchess of Connaught paid a short visit to the Y. W. C. A. Home and Institute at Cairo on Saturday afternoon, accompanied by Lady Cromer, and expressed herself pleased with what she saw, writing her name in the visitors’ book.

Suez Canal.—On the 25th and 26th ult. 25 vessels passed through the Canal. Of these 14 were British, 4 German, 1 Italian, 2 Norwegian, 1 French, 3 Dutch. The receipts for the two days were frs. 676,227.24, the total receipts from 1st February being frs. 9,031,832.21.

Shepheard’s Garden Fete, which is one of the most pleasant attractions of the Cairo season, has been fixed to take place on Thursday , 9th inst. The magnificent gardens ot the hotel will, as usual, be beautifully illuminated, and confetti battles will rage with their accustomed fury. A military band and the Tzigane orchestra will supply the music alternately during the evening. Invitations for the fête are to be issued this week.

Visitors to Egypt who will shortly be contemplating the return journey to Europe should note that the next sailing of the White Star Line from Alexandria will take place on Thursday next, 9th inst., when the S.S. ‘‘Canopic” will leave for Naples (reached in three days) and America. This steamer will be followed by the “Republic” on the 16th inst., and the “Romanic” on the 30th inst. The fares from Alexandria to Naples are £10 and upwards. Bookings may be effected at the White Star agents in Alexandria, Messrs. J. Ross and Co., and at Cook’s tourist offices, in Cairo.

The Italian Charity Fancy-dress Ball will take place on Friday next, 3rd inst., in the temporary ball-room constructed in the Ezbekieh Gardens. There will be three prizes, viz., one for the finest and- most elegant tume, one for the best group of masks, and one for the most original costume. The Soarez operetta company will enter at midnight, forming an allegorical procession, and will dance a minuet. The ball, which promises to be brilliantly successful, will be under the patronage of the Marquis di Salvago-Raggi and the Marquis di Sorogna.

A. L. M. & D. S.—We regret that pressure on our space prevents us from giving account to-day of the excellent concert held at the New Khedivial Hotel last night under the auspices of the Alexandria Literary Musical and Dramatic Society. We hear that there are some interesting lectures in prospect for the members of the society. The Rev, Reginald Rynd has promised a series of two or three lectures on the “History or Philosophy of Music and Acoustics.” Mr. Rynd’s musical training at St. Michael’s College and the fact, that he is a Choral Scholar of Magdalen College, Oxford, give him great authority to speak on such subjects. Later on in the season, on the return of Dr. Ruffer from Tor, we are to expect an illustrated lecture from him on Mount Sinai. There is also a prospect of a dramatic performance being staged before very long. The pieces being rehearsed are “The Dowager” and “Petticoat Perfidy.” Another idea is also afloat of an artistic nature in the shape an Art Loan Exhibition. An oratorio is likewise being practised by the St. Mark’s Choir and the Choral Union, which, it is hoped, will be ready by the end of March. In fact, people are beginning to recover from the effects of influenza and the cold, wet winter season.

div.head: OUR ROYAL VISITORS.
div.p: Last Day of Visit.

While H.R.H. the Duke of Connaught spent the whole of yesterday inspecting the various units of the British garrison at Alexandria, the Duchess of Connaught and the Princesses, accompanied by H.R.H. Prince Gustavus Adolphus and their suites, passed the forenoon in visiting the Greco-Roman Museum, the Victoria Column; and Kom el-Shougafah excavations. At 1 p.m. they lunched at General’s House and at 3.30 p.m. drove to the Anto-niadis Gardens. They subsequently took tea in the Nouzha Gardens and drove back to the Arsenal wharf at 5:30 p.m., when they embarked on H.M.S. “Essex.”

T.R.H. the Duke and Duchess of Connaught the Princesses Margaret and Patricia, H.R.H. Prince Gustavus Adolphus of Sweden and Norway, and their suites left the Arsenal wharf at 10.30 a.m. to-day by a special train, put at their disposition by the Khedive, and proceeded to Aboukir to visit the scene of the Battle of the Nile. On the way ,to Aboukir the train stopped at Moutazah to enable the Royal visitors to have a look at the Khédivial demesne.
The Royal party visited Nelson Island in the Coastguard Administration’s launch.
Mr. and Mrs. Crafton placed their villa at Aboukir at the disposal of the Royal party, and they partook of lunch there.

The Royal party will return this afternoon by the same train, leaving Aboukir at 3.30 p.m. and arriving at the Arsenal at 4.10 p.m. They will embark on H.M.S. “Essex,” which is expected to leave shortly after for Cyprus.
THE KHEDIVE.
H.H. the Khedive passed yesterday morning at Koubbeh Palace. On Tuesday next he will give a great reception at Abdeen Palace on the occasion of the beginning of the Moslem New Year 1323 A.H.
The Khedivah will hold a reception at Koubbeh Palace on the same day.
His Highness has bestowed the following decorations :
Osmanieh, Grand Cordon (1st Class): Prince Gustavus Adolphus of Sweden and Norway.
Medjidieh, Grand Cordon, (1st Class): Mr. Belinfante Ostberg, Swedish and Norwegian Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General.
Medjidieh, Grand Officer, (2nd Class): Baron de Ralamb.
Medjidieh, Commander, (3rd Class): Captain Sverre.
The following have been promoted in rank :
Sanieh : Mohamed Rahmi Bey, Saad Khalil Bey.
Salissah : Mikhaïl Accladios Effendi, Mohamed Ismail Effendi.
Medjidieh, Officer (4th class) : Bimbashi Mohamed Effendi Safouat Capudan.
SHAH AND KHEDIVE.

At 10 a.m. to-day, Ahmed Pasha Zeky, Khédivial Grand Master of Ceremonies, drove in a State carriage to the Persian Agency, and afterwards conducted Mirza Ali Asghar Khan to Abdeen Palace, where a detachment of Egyptian troops paid the usual honors to the Persian Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General.

At 10.30 a.m. H.H. the Khedive, with the Ministers, received the Persian diplomat, who handed to his Highness the brevet and insignia of the “Timsal Hamayuni” Order, accompanied by an autograph letter from H.M. the Shah.
The usual complimentary speeches were exchanged.
FINANCE MINISTRY.
The following changes will take place in the Finance Ministry in consequence of the aboli tion of the post of Director General of the Accounts Department on the resignation of Harari Pasha.
Mr. Roussin, late of the Anglo-Egyptian Bank, will be Director of the Treasury of the Finance Ministry.
P. Mesciaca Bey, Director of the Central Treasury and Secretary of the Finance Committee, will be appointed Controller of the Treasury Department.
Auguste Bey Adib, Director, Central Ac counts aud Budget Department, will be appointed Controller of the Accounts Department
B. Atallah Bey, Sub-Director of the Central Treasury, will be the Director of Accounts.
MARSA MATROUH.

It is announced that all applications for grants of lands at Marsa-Matrouh or in its vicinity, either to the Ministry of Finance or to any other Department, will not for the present be taken into consideration.
STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
The Ellerman S.S. “Adalia” left Malta on Wednesday and is expected here on Sunday morning, with passengers, mails and general cargo.
The Ellerman S. S. “Athenian” sailed from Liverpool on Wednesday and is expected here with general cargo on or about, the 15th inst.
The Westcott S.S. “Flavian” sailed yesterday for Odessa.
The S.S. “Royal Prince” left London on Wednesday, with passengers and a general cargo, for Malta and Alexandria.
The S.S. "Grecian Prince" arrived in Manchester from Alexandria yesterday.

div.head: THE TRADE OF EGYPT.
div.p: JANUARY RETURNS.

The growing wealth of Egypt is much in evidence in the Customs returns for January, and we have begun the year well with an increase of L.E. 363,926 on the imports for the corresponding month last year, the total imports being LE. 1,779,107, as against L.E 1,415,181. Considering that 1904 showed rapid and consistent upward tendency in the imports, which resulted in a surplus of over L.E 3,300,000 in the value of the imports over the previous year, if the present year keeps up the same ratio throughout, as it has commenced with in the import returns for January, 1905 should see the total value of its imports considerably over the LE. 20,000,000 of last year’s imports.

As usual in January the total imports are less than in the preceding December. The great activity and demand for goods during the marketing of the cotton crop from September onwards, culminating in the large clearances during December to settle up accounts, usually bring about a set-back in the volume of imports at the turn of the year. The returns for the month of January, 1904, show no exception to the rule, the imports for that month being considerably less in value than those for December, which had total value of L.E. 2,418,750.

The total value of the imports from Great Britain and British Mediterranean possessions was LE. 543,526, as against LE. 494,240 in January of 1904. England sent cotton fabrics to the value of L.E 243,883 to Egypt last month, as against LE. 180,203 in the corresponding month last year ; iron and steel to the value of L.E. 47,751, as against LE. 37,583 ; brass, copper, and bronze, L.E. 18,060, as against L.E. 19,264 ; coal, L.E. 23,348, as against L.E. 79,107. However, on the whole, England by no means held her own satisfactorily as regards imports in January, for whereas the increase in the total amount of imports was 20 4 per cent., that of British imports was but 83 per cent.
EXPORTS.

The total exports during January amounted in value to L.E. 1,893,751, as against L.E 2,673,474 in January, 1904, a decrease of L.E. 779,723. This is easily accounted for by the decrease in the cotton exports. Last January the cotton exported amounted to 689,929 cantors, valued at L.E. 1,476,245. In January, 1904, 790,492 cantors were exported, of the value of L.E. 2,330,117. Thus, owing to the fall in the price of cotton, although only 100,563 cantors less were exported, the decrease in value amounted to L.E. 853,872.

In examining these monthly returns care must be taken to distinguish between purely accidental and temporary changes and those which indicate a more or less continuous displace-ment of trade. To the former category belong the fall in the value of the exports in the first month of this year. Bean exports decreased by 8,502 ardebs, a decrease in value of L.E. 6,820. Egg exports fell off by L.E. 7,444, only fifteen million eggs having left the country, as against twenty-nine million in January, 1904. Oilcake exports show an increase of L.E. 5,847, but the greatest development was shown in cane sugar, which increased by 142,785 cantars, of the value of L.E. 73,193. The cotton yarn imports from England amounted to L.E. 16,244 out of a total of L.E. 20,418 imported that month, an increase of LE. 3,397 on the total for the corresponding month last year. Italy sent cotton yarns to the value of L.E. 4,611 and is making rapid progress in this class of import. It is worth noting.

In regard to the import of cotton yarns, the imports at Alexandria from the United Kingdom show that during last year a large falling-off occurred. In 1902 they amounted to LE 106,533, in 1903 to L.E 79,545, and in 1904 to L.E. 63,046. This decline is attributable to the advancing prices in Manchester at a time when Bombay yarns were unusually depressed. These latter, being then so much cheaper than British yarns, quickly found their way into this market, and the imports rose from £6,600 in 1902 to about £43,000 in 1904. It is very probable, however, that British yarns will easily regain their former position when their value falls within the limit which native weavers can afford to pay. Italian sewings do not seem to have made further progress. In fact, if we make allowance for increase in value the figure for 1904 (L.E 28,815) seems to show that a slightly smaller quantity has entered the country than in 1903 (LE. 28,786) The notable increase in the importation of mercerised yarns may be attributed to the same cause as that above-mentioned as account ing for the increase in “Fancy Goods.”

div.head: EGYPTIAN SHARE MARKET.
div.p: (From our Financial Correspondent.)

London, February 24. Of the Japanese and the Russians it may be said that they do protest too much. The constant denials of any negotiations for peace are considered rather a confirmation of the rumours. The various “balons d’essai” that have been thrown out have undoubtedly been for the purpose of obtaining the views of the people and the Powers on the subjects to be discussed, and are intended to make the negotiations easier when they arrive at a crucial stage. The march of events in Manchuria and in Russia are calculated to make a speedy peace a necessity, of which every day as it passes increases the urgency.

The House has, at any rate, convinced itself that prospects are rosy, and members have been advising their clients to take up low-priced high-grade investment securities before they suddenly find they will be unable to procure them at a price paying them over 3 per cent. The levelling-up process has gone steadily on, and although there has been a slight reaction in Consols, which are to-day quoted at 90 7/8, there has been no looking back in the case of securities that are sound and remunerative.

The issue by Messrs. Speyer Brothers of £3,000,000 4 per cent Grand Trunk Railway Loan has been largely subscribed, and while further large issues by the same firm are promised, they are rather looked forward to thau dreaded, as would have been the case some months ago. Accumulations of capital would appear to be large, and are finding their way to the stock markets now that the political horizon is becoming clearer.

The public are still determined to be on the safe side, and no considerable portion of idle capital is, it would appear, being directed towards the more speculative securities. The market for South African and other mining shares has been dull, though having a strong undertone. Japanese stocks are naturally buoyant, and, although not far short of the highest points yet touched, are still a strong market. The speculation in bank shares is still the leading, feature in Egyptians, and the National Banks during the early part of the week rose as high as 281/4. At this price they yield something like 2 1/2 per cent., that is, less than Consols, and although the future may, and in fact should, show them to be well worth it, such justification as there is for such a price is based on anticipations. Agricultural Bank shares, in which the announcement of 6s. dividend has caused a slight setback, as it was just up to market expectations, and left nothing to go for, are steady at 11 1/2. Daira Sanieh shares are firm and well-supported at 25. The new Corporation of Western Egypt are at 3/8 premium. Egyptian mining shares do not fall, but are idle with the other mining markets, which have not yet come in for a share of the better business tone now prevailing.
SOCIETE EGYPTIENNE D’ELECTRICITE.

The Société Anonyme Egyptienne d’Elec tricité is about to make an issue of 6,500 £4 shares at par for the purpose of increasing its capital. The public subscription for these shares, after deducting those reserved for present shareholders, which has been opened at the National Bank of Egypt, will close tomorrow (Friday) at 5 p.m.
ALEXANDRIA’S WATER SUPPLY.

The Municipal Commission has decided that steps should be taken in view of the complaints from the Water Company, and the statements of the Prisons Department and of Dr. Gotschlich, to look thoroughly into the question of the pollution through the Mah-moudieh Canal of the water supply of Alexandria. For this purpose Mr. Foster, Dr. Schiess Bey, and Mr. Williams have been delegated by the Municipality to form part of the commission of enquiry into this serious matter affecting the health of the entire city. The Ministry of the Interior has been approached by the Municipality to appoint Government representatives to sit on the commission, which, it is hoped, will find an early and satisfactory solution of this vital problem.
a musical event.

The Choral Society of Vienna is expected to arrive at Alexandria on the 23rd inst. on board a specially chartered Austrian Lloyd steamer. The famous hand of musicians will give a concert here on the evening of the 23rd and spend the night on hoard the vessel, going the following morning to Cairo, where they are to give two concerts. The Choral Society of Vienna is composed of a whole battalion musicians (i.e., two hundred) and difficulty has been found in finding accommodation for them in the Capitol, but Nungovich Bey has taken the matter in hand, and hence the problem may be said to have been solved. The members of the society are recruited from among the best classes of Viennese society, and this explains the tact of their being able to undertake such a long journey at their own expense. Moreover, the proceeds of the con certs here will go to swell the funds of local charities. That is their principle. They have observed it wherever they have gone to seek fresh laurels, in London, Paris, Berlin, Brus sels, Constantinople, etc. In Cairo a reception worthy of the combination is being prepared for them. A committee has been formed under high patronage to see that, in exchange for the rare treat which they are to provide us with, the society will hear away with them the pleasantest souvenirs of their stay fo the country.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: H.R.H. the Duke of Connaught him presented Nungovich Bey with a charm in the shape of a precious stone on which the Duke’s initials are engraved, surrounded by brilliants in the form of a crown. Nungovich Bey was in charge of all the arrangements daring the Royal visit to Cairo and thé Sudan.
Boutros Pasha Ghah, the Judicial Adviser, and Messrs. Rocca Serra, Brunyate, and Ber-nardi arrive at Alexandria to-day for to-morrow’s meeting of the International Commission of the Mixed Tribunals.
Messrs. G. B. Hornblower and A. S. Mon-teith-Smith have been confirmed in their appointments as inspectors to the Ministry of the Interior, with salaries of L.E.60 per mensem.

Dr. B. Barnett, Assistant Medical Officer of Health, Hong Kong, is leaving that Colony to take up duty as Assistant Inspector of Hospitals in Egypt. Dr. Barnett before proceeding to Hong Kong in 1903 was Assistant Medical Registrar of St George’s Hospital, London.

Mr. T. Oliver, the energetic representative of Messrs. Maple & Co., left for home yesterday on the North German Lloyd steamer “Hohen-zollern.” If report is correct, Mr. Oliver is to be congratulated on the success of his trip. During his two seasons’ visits in this country he has certainly made himself a “persona grata” with all those desirous of availing themselves of his services and advice connected with his business, as well as socially.
SPORT AND PLAY.
FOOTBALL.
Saint Andrew’s Football Club
versus
Departmental’ Corps, Royal Berkshiress.

The above teams met on the ground of the former on Moharrem Bey common on Saturday last, when a very finely contested game was witnessed. The Saints won the toss and kicked with the wind in the first half. Some nice play was witnessed on both sides, and both defences were visited in turn. For the visitors, Murphy and Spencer were playing a nice game, while on the home side Keill, Cruise, and Another were conspicuous. The homesters looked dangerous on several occasions, but it was not until close on half-time that Keill beat Mullard with a shot which gave him no chance to save. The interval arrived with the Saints leading by 1—0.

The visitors were early in evidence in the second half and Curtis was tested by Spencer and had to concede a corner. This was well placed and Ryan headed through, thus putting his team level. Again the visitors troubled the homesters’ defence, and four corners in succession looked very bad for Saint Andrew’s. From one of these Godfrey had hard lines in not scoring, but Curtis saved in capital style. Later Shea had the goal at his mercy, but kicked high over the bar, when only a yard out. The Saints were showing some pretty forward play, Sweet and MacLardy combining well, and Cowie feeding his wing men nicely. Despite all efforts, however, they could seldom get into Mullard’s territory. The visitors’ halves were assisting both backs and forwards in capital style, Fuller particularly playing an excellent game. Another corner came the way of the Berks men, and from this Ryan scored a second for his side, again giving Curtis no chance to save. From this stage the Saints seldom got away, and but for the sterling defence of Curtis, Cruise, and another they would have been more heavily defeated. No further scoring took place, however, and the Departmental Corps thus retired victors by 2 -1. The following were the teams
Saint Andrew’s:—Curtis, A. N. Other, Cruise, Williams, Mace, Keill, Sweet, MacLardy, Cowie, Jones and Tulloch.
Departmental Corps :— Mullard, Godfrey, Deighton, Adams, Kindlen, Fuller, Sanderson, Ryan, Murphy, Shea, and Spencer.
Linesmen :—Messulum and Webb. Referee, Corporal Fitzgerald.

div.head: Commission Municipale
div.p: (Communication Officielle)
La Commission Municipale s’est réuni le 1er Mars 1905 a 4 p.m. sous la présidence do S.E. Mahmoud Pacha Sidky.

Présents MM. Amb. A. Ralli, vice-président, Abdel Moneim Bey Dalil, Ahmed Bey Yehia, Em. Benachi, Hussein Bey Riaz, A. Cumbo, L. Escoffier, P. Fenderl, E. W. P. Foster, Baron A. de Menasce, Ahmed Bey Talaat, O. Rotha-ker, A Padoa Bey, Dr. Schiess Bey, E. Stross, T. Suzzarini, Dr. Valensin, G. Zervudachi, membres, W. P. Chataway, administrateur, I. Sedky Bey, secrétaire.

Le Président présente à l’assemblée M. Ahmed Bey Talaat, nouveau chef du Parquet indigène, et membre de droit de la Commission. Il ne doute pas que suivant les traces de son prédécesseur Talaat Bey n’apporte au service de la ville le même dévouement et le même concours éclairé.
Talaat Bey remercie et dit qu’il s’efforcera de mériter la confiance de l’assemblée.

Communication est donnée d’une lettre du 27 février 1905 de M. Alderson informant que n’ayant pas obtenu le vote de la Commission pour être membre de la Délégation, il croit devoir maintenir sa démission. Si cependant la Commission acceptait sa proposition tendant à permettre à tous les membres d’assister aux séances de la Délégation, il serait heureux de demander à l’assemblée de retirer sa démission.
Après un échange d’idées, la Commission au scrutin secret, accepte par 15 voix contre 2 et une abstention, la démission de M. Alderson.

Communication est donnée d’une lettre du 28 février de S.E. le Ministre de l’Intérieur informant qu’il approuve la désignation de MM. Rothaker et Foster comme membres de la Commission chargée d’étudier la question des terrains à réserver au Gouvernement sur les quais d’Alexandrie.

Lecture est donnée d’une lettre du 22 février 1905 de S. E. le Ministre de l’Intérieur transmettant l’avis du Comité du Contentieux de l’Etat au sujet des automobiles publics pour le transport des marchandises ou des personnes. L'avis conclut à ce que ces automobiles ne peuvent être mises en circulation qu’en vertu d’une autorisation préalable du Gouvernorat qui fixera les conditions relatives à la voirie et à la sécurité publique. Il appartiendra à la Municipalité de fixer le tarif de ces automobiles et la redevance annuelle à percevoir.

Le Comité du Contentieux de la Municipalité a adopté cette manière de voir sous la réserve que s’agissant d’autorisations intéres sant les voies publiques au point de vue surtout du poids et de la conformation des véhicules et de leur influence sur les chaussées il y a lieu de suivre pour ces autorisations une procédure semblable à celle pratiquée pour les établissements insalubres, c.a.d. que l’avis conforme de la Municipalité doit être requis et la redevance acquittée avant la remise de l’autorisation.
Cette redevance sera établie pour chaque demande, suivant les cas.
La Commission renvoie la question pour suite voulue à la Délégation, qui s’inspirera dans l'execution des idees developpees par le Comit du Contentieux.
Une demande de gratification presentee par un fonctionnaire retraite, n'est pas acceptee.
Un credit supplementaire de L.E. 60, a prelever sur la reserve du budget ordinaire pour certaines reparations a effectuer a l'abattoir est adopte.
Vu les resultats du concours ouvert pour un poste d'ingenieur et le classement fait par la Delegation, la Commission designe a ce poste M. l'ingenieur Pangalos.
Le poste occupe par ce dernier dans la classe de L.E. 16 a 20 sera mis au concours.
M. le Dr. Delta est nomme a titre definitif au poste d'assistant bacteriologue de l'Inspecteur Sanitaire dans la classe de L.E. 22 a 26.
M. le Dr. Alpar, charge du service des moeurs a l'hopital du gouvernement, est nomme medecin des moeurs dans la classe de L.E. 16 a 20.
Une proposition de M. O. Joseph pour la construction d'une jetee promenade au quai du Port Est, est renvoyee a l'etude des Comites des Finances et des Travaux Publics.
Le reglement d'application de la taxe sur les carrieres est adopte.
Le Vice-president fait rapport au sujet des demandes presentees pour l'inscription dans les listes electorales, a la suite de leur affichage.
L'examen de ces reclamations est ajourne a la prochaine seance.
La Commission autorise l'Administration a ester en justice dans diverses affaires judiciaires.

Aucun mmebre de la Commission ne s'etant approprie la proposition de Mr. Alderson tendant a l'assistance des Conseillers aux reunions de la Delegation, cette proposition tombre par le fait que son auteur n'est plus memebre de l'assemblee.
La seance est levee a 7 h. 1/4 pm.

div.head: CAISSE DE LA DETTE
div.p: Emprunt Garanti 3 o/o

Amortissement du 1er Mare. — Les fonds applicables à l’amortissement s’élèvent à LE. 65,313/757, qui se décomposent comme suit : Solde du semestre précédent L.E.54/371, pro duit des biens libres catalogués et recouvrement d’arriérés à fin 1879 LE.28,435/099 et dotation d’amortissement du 1er Mare 1905 L.E.36,824/287.
Ces fonds ont été consacrés au tirage au sort du 14 décembre 1904 pour la somme de £ 66,900 nominales, remboursable au pair, soit L.E.65,227/500. Le reste, LE.86/257, forme le solde disponible.
Par suite de cet amortissement, le capital de l’Emprunt Garanti 3 %, qui était pour l’échéance du 1er mars 1905de £ nominales 7,982,100, se trouve réduit à £ nominales 7,915,200.
La demi-annuité fixe de £157,500 du 1er septembre 1905 se décomposera comme suit : £118,728, dotation d’intérêts, £38,772, dota tion d’amortissement.

div.head: DELEGATION MUNICIPALE.
div.p: (Communication Officielle.)
La Délégation Municipale s’est réunie le 28 février 1905 à 4 h. p.m. sous la présidence de M. Amb. A. Ralli.
Présents : MM. Benachi, Fenderl, E. Stross, Dr G. Valensin, G. Zervudachi, membres, W. P. Chataway, administrateur ; I. Sedky Bey, secrétaire.
La Délégation décide de rappeler à la police l’application du nouveau tarif pour les voitures élaboré par la Commission Municipale.

Elle émet un avis favorable à la proposition du service des recettes appuyé par les services sanitaires et techniques tendant à l’augmentation des gratifications accordées annuellement aux cheikhs el hara en raison des services qu’ils rendent à ces divers bureaux. Mais elle estime que la proposition à faire à ce sujet à la Commission doit attendre la fin de l’exercice afin que l'Administration soit en mesure de juger si ces agents se sont montres a la hauteur des taches qui leur sont confiees.
La Delegation adjuge.
1. A Abdel Rahim Kenawi la fourniture de chars pour le transport des dalles.
2. A M. Romanelli, la fourniture de sable.
3. A Mahmoud Ismail les immondices de Ramleh et le fumier des ecuries municipales de Bulkeley.
4. A M. A. Marino, au prix de 180 L.E. les travaux de dellage des rues Chimi bey, Mustafa, el Arab, Zawiet el Wardian, Gouda et Taher bey.
5. A M. Moscatelli, au prix de L.E. 283 le dallage des rues Moussafarkhane el Helal, Sidi Daoud et 2 ruelles pres de Mawazini.
La Direction procede a l'examen du rapport de M. Piot bey sur les operations du service veterinaire pendant l'annee 1904 et prend a ce sijet les deliberations suivantes:

a) elle charge le service technique d'etablir le devis de la construction d'une salle exclusivement destinee aux betes suspetes ainsi que d'une toiture recouvrant l'espace compris entre les deux salles d'abatage du gros et du petit betail.

b) elle demande egalement prealablement a l'etude de la question par le Comite des travaux publics un devis des frais necessites par la construction de plus vastes locaux pour les porcs et pour prevenir l'entassement des animaux vivants.

c) Elle demande a l'inspecteur sanitaire un rapport sur les moyens de remedier aux conditions defectueuese dans lesquelles s'opere le voyage des animaux provenant de Syrie et des autres pays en general ainsi que sur la nourriture de ces animaux, soit en cours de route soit dans les parcs quarantenaires. Il y aurait lieu a cet egard de se mettre en rapport avec le conseil quarantenaire sur les moyens a adopter. Il devrait egalement etre interdit d'abattre les betes aussitot leur arrivee.

d) Au sujet de la question des abreuvoirs publics, qui d'apres l'opinion de M. Piot bey seraient une cause de developpement de la morve, la Delegation demande des renseignements sur les methodes adoptees a l'etranger et les precautions prises; en attendant elle demande a l'Administration de veiller a ce que les abreuvoirs existants soient frequemment laves.

e) La Delegation demandera a la Commission d'ajouter au reglement sur la morve une disposition permettant en tout temps au service veterinaire de proceder a la malleinisation des solipedes d'une ecurie, meme si aucun cas de morve n'a ete constate.
La Commission voudra bien en meme temps ouvrir les credits voulus pour les indemnites qui en resulteraient.
f) Elle demande une note a M. Palmer sur la question des salaries des conducteurs, de leur engagement, de leur inexrience, questions soulevees dans le dit rapport.
La Delegation decide de reserver autour de l'ouverture de l'hypogee d'Anfouchy une place et elle demnadera au Gouvernement une parcelle equivalente pour etre donnee en echange au Wakf Abou Siri.
La seance est levee a 8 h. p.m.

div.head: THE RAILWAY COMMISSION.
div.p: TEXT OF THE REPORT.
ENGINEERING DEPARTMENT. {Continued}.

We think that if improved pay can be afforded to the superior officers, their periods of leàve should at the same time be more strictly defined with a view to a certain proportion of their number being always left in Egypt. A large railway is a machine which can never cease working night or day, and demands the continuous presence of its guiding hands. A definite age limit should also be introduced, in order to keep the service efficient, and some arrangement must be come to, if the railway is to be worked on commercial lines, for enabling unsatisfactory employés to be dispensed with promptly.
I._(a) AUDITING AND ACCOUNTS.

A note upon the working of this Department (which we find was in course of reorganisation) is given in the Appendix. Beyond this we feel it very desirable that once a year some outside Auditor should be employed by the Government to examine the Railway accounts and to make a report thereon.
II.- To indicate the manner in which the capital sum at the disposal of the Government may most advantageously be applied.
(a). In bringing the existing system up to date, and providing the rolling stock necessary to enable it to cope with the rapidly increasing demands of the public.
The best method of employing the sum now at the disposal of the Government is the problem to which we have devoted the most continuous attention during our stay in this country.
We are of opinion that the immediate necessities group themselves under the following heads in order of importance :—
Rolling Stock. Alexandria Improvements. Track and Signalling (including station improvements). Fencing. New Lines.

We have had some difficulty in arriving at final figures, because the amount available for doubling and for new lines must necessarily depend upon the condition to which it is desired to bring the existing railway.

As regards the track itself, the position may fairly be summed up by saying that whereas in 1887 nine-tenths of the track were in a bad state and only one-tenth fair, to-day one-tenth is bad and nine-tenths are fair.

While we do not consider it necessary that any, except the chief main lines, should he brought up to European standard, we think that|he time has come when these chief main lines, especially Cairo-Alexandria, Cairo-Port Said and Cairo-Luxor, should be equipped with all reasonably safety appliances, the stations and sidings improved, the track ballasted to prevent the intolerable dust, while certain lengths should be fenced.

But it is exceedingly difficult to make estimates in detail, especially on the minor lines, since engineers’ plans and estimates were not prepared, and the figures given by us must therefore he taken as approximate.

We are impressed with the fact that though the traffic in the Delta is far heavier and, owing to the number of junctions and express trains, far more difficult to work than in Upper Egypt, the money hitherto spent on improvements has been less in the Delta.

Large schemes for reconstruction of stations and doubling of lines, etc., are planned in Upper Egypt, but we are strongly of opinion that the Delta lines and Ports should be taken in hand first, for the crux of the traffic position is in the Ports and the approaches thereto, and it is useless to make provision for sending down large masses of traffic to Cairo and Teh el-Baroud if the neck of the bottle is blocked It will be seen therefore, from the details appended under the heading of Improvements to Stations, that we have allocated a larger sum to Lower than to Upper Egypt.

As regards Carriages and Wagons, we have not the slightest hesitation in recommending immediate purchases of both. The graphic tables appended show the extraordinary development of passenger movement, and though goods receipts are less elastic, there is no question that traffic is being both stopped and diverted to other routes owing to lack of wagons.

It will be seen from the Summary given on page 13 that we think for a sum of L.E. 2,223,750 the State Railways can be brought into a condition of much greater physical efficiency. though of course they would even then not reach the first-class European standard, and we allot in addition the sum of L.E.700,000 for the construction of new lines.

We feel strongly that this money should be spent on a definite plan of urgency, the Chief Officer, together with the Engineer and Traffic Manager, considering the railway system as a whole, making a plan and estimate in each case and dealing with the work accordingly. Even then the execution will take some time. II.—(b) CONSTRUCTION OF NEW LINES.
In our estimates the sum necessary for the construction of the following new lines is included :-
a. Salhieh to Kantara . . . L.E. 70,000
b. Defrah to Santah . . . ,, 80,000
c. Zifteh to Zagazig . . . ,, 400,000
d. Achemoun to Barrage. . . ,, 150,000

We do not feel justified in expressing an opinion on what lines are the most advantageous for the country generally, but we have included the above only because we understand that their construction has been already decided upon. In the following paragraphs we have however indicated that we think the project for a narrow-gauge line of about 200 miles from Assouan to Wady Haifa is well worthy of consideration.
Keneh to Assouan.
Our opinion is asked as to the “advisability of broading the gauge from the Luxor to Assouan," a distance of 213 kilometres where the gauge is at present 3 feet 6 inches.
The rails are the flat bottomed or Vignole type, weighing approximately 42 lbs. to the yard.
They are laid on uncreosoted pine sleepers with a bearing plate under the rail.
The Grades are not excessive, 1 in 125 being the worst, nor are the curves for a 3 ft. 6 in. gauge very sharp, 200 metres radius being the minimum.

The Permanent Way is comparatively new ; the line was constructed in 1896-97 and opened for traffic in 1898. The rails are very little Worn and the sleepers, as far as we could see, showed no signs of deterioration.

The traffic on this line is very light, consisting of one passenger train each way daily, and one mixed passenger and goods train. An extra goods train is run when necessary. The traffic chiefly consists of goods to and from the Sudan ; the tonnage dealt with at the intermediate stations is practically nil.
There is also some tourist traffic to Assouan for about 3 months in the winter.

In our opinion there is but small possibility of any rapid development in the goods traffic. We consider that the existing line with the 3 foot 6 inch gauge is fully able to deal with a far larger goods and passenger traffic than it is now called upon to carry.

The engines and rolling stock are well maintained, and appear to be sufficient for present requirements. We think that more attention should be given to the signals, and that the ordinary telegraph order system is well suited for working the trains on this line, and should be substituted for the present method ot crossing trains by telephonic communication. In the Appendix will be found details of the money, viz : about LE. 25,000, which we consider should be spent on this piece of line (beyond the ordinary revenue charges). Should there be a further development of passenger traffic, it is probable that a few more coaches may be required.

In view of the large sum of money which is to be spent on other parts of the Railway system, and having regard to the doubt as to the immediate growth of traffic in this district, we are of opinion that it would not be wise to alter the gauge of this line.

The 4 foot 8 1/2 inch gauge could not be laid without considerable modifications, and the flattening of existing curves ; the cost would probably reach L.E. 600,000. Unless, therefore J the whole existing material and rolling stock could be satisfactorily disposed of, we cannot recommend that any alteration should be made to the gauge of this line ; the expenditure would not be remunerative, and this is a point we were specially requested to bear in mind when making our recommendations.
If the new Barrage is made at Esneh, we think that arrangements might be made for taking a line of rail over it, so as to tap the large new district now being brought into cultivation there.
We also see that the gauge of this line (3

div.head: Dr. Tibbles Vi-Cocoa
div.p: A LETTER... FROM GIBRALTAR.
A CHEERFUL SHIP’S COMPANY SINCE USING VI-COCOA.
Mr..W. CATERER, 3 Mess, H.M.S. “FORMIDARLE,” Gibraltar, writes:—

“I have the pleasure of writing to you to express our opinion as regards to your valuable Vi-Cocoa. We have had rather arduous times since we left Portsmouth, a month ago, having had to coal ship four times, being mostly night work. Whilst in the collier shovelling and hauling bags about we have become very tired and languid, and when we get a little time to have our meals we have made a nice drop of Vi-Cocoa, which is both refreshing and nourishing, and when we turn to our work we seem as though we could carry on with our work for a much longer time without feeling fatigued. Of course we could not do so if we had not take, Vi-Cocoa.

We all use it in this mess every morning, as we find it more sustaining than the ordinary ship’s cocoa which the Service allows us. We have recommended it to all our shipmates. There is a lot of remarks passed by several of the ship's company about all our messmates being so bright and cheerful, and they ask us the reason as we all belong to what is called in this ship as the comical party and we tell them that Vi-Cocoa makes us like it, and they say they will give it a trial.
“You are at liberty to publish this letter of praise as you please.”
You must have read the striking testimony that is being published daily respecting the merits of Vi-Coooa. And yet you have not tried it. We advise you to do so at once.

Dr. Tibbles’ vi-Cocoa can be obtained in 6d. tins from all grocers; or the Proprietors will send you -free a dainty sample tin upon receipt of a postcard to 60 Bunhill Row, London. E.C. asking them to do so.

feet 6 inches) is the same as that of the Sudan Railway, of which 700 miles are already laid, and more are under construction. It seems to us that the gap of only 200 miles must sooner or later be bridged, and that when this is done, Luxor will be quite as convenient a transhipping place as Assouan, Luxor being being a day or a night’s journey from Cairo (673 kilometres) for passengers, and possessing the necessary fitting shops, &c., which Assouan does not possess.

We have little doubt that it would pay better to spend about L.E. 1,000,000 upon linking up the two systems than L.E. 600,000 upon widening the existing Luxor-Assouan gauge, and we think that the project of uniting the two systems, the Egyptian of 1,667 miles, and the Sudanese of 700 miles, is most worthy of immediate attention and study, as being quite likely to give a return on the capital in a comparatively short time.
(To be continued).

div.head: THE NURSE IN PEACE AND WAR.
div.p: Everyone believes a Nurse. War Correspondents praise her ; those who need her help in Peace trust her implicitly. Hence the following words from a trusted and intelligent hospital helper, Nurse Brailsford, of Horsforth, near Leeds, are worthy of attention :—

“In the course of my long experience,” said the Nurse, “I have met with many cases in which Dr. Williams’ pink pills have proved a boon to sufferers. I recall one case in which this medicine effected a remarkable cure. A young lady had suffered six months from an ulcerated stomach following anæmia. She was as pale as a sheet, and looked as if she had not a drop of blood in her.

“The invalid came to stay with me. She was weak as a kitten, unable to walk many yards without assistance. I had to take her for drives at first to get her into the fresh air. Her digestion was so poor she had to live on liquid food.

“Just before she came to me, her mother had bought her a box of Dr. Williams’ pink pills for pale people, and she began to take them regularly. As she seemed entirely bloodless, she could not do better than take a medicine which makes new blood. These pills are just what anæmic girls require. After a few days, she began to drink milk and eat solid food. Slowly but surely she regained her appetite. Her stomach became stronger, and, as it was able to retain solid food, she soon gained energy, and was able to walk some distance. The paleness of her face was gradually replaced by a healthy colour. After three months with me, the young lady went home absolutely cured. When her mother saw her she exclaimed, ‘I never saw a girl so much improved in my life.’ Dr. Williams’ pink pills were the sole means of her cure. I can vouch for the fact that she took no other medicine.”

Whole families sometimes fall victims to anæmia—men are not exempt. Dr. Williams’ pink pills supply rich red blood to the starved veins and quickly banish many of the weaknesses and pains that afflict the weaker sex. But they are equally valuable for men, having cured indigestion, anæmia, palpitations, bile, nervous depression, sciatica, rheumatism, paralysis St. Vitus’ dance, and nervous disorders. Genuine pills bear the full name, Dr. Williams’ pink pills for pale people. If pestered with substitutes, it is best to go to another shopkeeper ; or, in case of doubt, send two shillings and ninepence for one box, or thirteen and nine pencê for six boxes, to Dr. Williams’ medicine co., Holbom viaduct, London.
Sold in Egypt by all chemists at P.T. 13 per box or P.T. 70 per 6 boxes. Can be bought at the general depot : Max Fischer, Cairo, Hotel du Nil St. (1st floor), and Alexandria, Rue Stamboul, No. 8.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves for the responsible opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit- within certain necessary limits- free discussion.
A CAIRO SCANDAL.
To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette.

Dear Sir,—The recent festivities given by H.E. Yussuf Talaat Pasha on the occasion of the wedding of his daughter form a striking example to a subject which I have longed for some time to have seen discussed in your columns, namely that of the part played by the dragomen with regard to invitation cards. Those men, regardless of anything but their own immediate pecuniary gain, adopt a shameful way of extorting money out of their unaware employers. They take advantage of the kindness and hospitality of some of the people who happen to give a wedding during the tourist season, to get some invitation cards under the plea that some tourists are very anxious to be present at an Egyptian wedding and would be very grateful for an invitation. Having secured the cards, they return to their respective hotels, where they sell them at prices varying from twenty piastres to a sovereign. When the card holders, unaware of the fraud, go to the wedding, they think themselves entitled to all their moneyworth, the result being that certain unpleasantness occurs, causing a not very favorable impression of each other to be left in both parties’ minds.

As this preposterous and shameful state of things ought not to be allowed to go on, I thought that some warning given in your columus to our foreign visitors might have some good effect. Believe me, Dear Sir, to be, Yours truly, An Egyptian. Cairo, February 28.

div.head: Société Anonyme du Béhéra
div.p: AVIS

Messieurs les Actionnaires de la Anonyme du Béhéra sont convoqués en b|ée Générale Ordinaire le Mardi 14 Mars 1905, à 3 heures 1/2 de relevée au Siège de la Société, 6, Rue Adib, pour délibérer sur l’ordre du jour suivant :
(1) Audition du rapport du Conseil d’Administration sur les Affaires de la Société.
(2) Audition du rapport du Censeur.
(3) Approbation des Comptes de l’exercice 1904 et fixation du dividende.
(4) Nomination d’un censeur pour l’exercise 1905.
Et à l’issue de cette séanœ les actionnaires sont convoqués en assemblée générale extraordinaire pour délibérer sur l’ordre du jour suivaut :

(1) Proposition a) d’augmenter le capital de la société par la création de 100,000 actions privilégiées de £ 5 chacune, amortissables par tirage au sort au gré de la société et selon ses disponibilités et donnaut droit à un intérêt annuel et cumulatif de 5 %.

(b) de répartir actuellement 50,000 de ces actions privilégiées jouissance 1er Janvier 1905 à raison d’une action privilégiée pour chaque action ordinaire, en représentation des bénéfices acquis sur les reventes des terres de la Société.
(2) Modifications des articles 5, 7 et 38 des statuts comme sait :
ARTICLE 5 (1er paragraphe)
Texts Actuel
Le fonds social est fixe a la somme de L.E. 250.000 divisee en 50.000 Actions de L.E. 5 chacune.
Texte Propose

Le fonds social est fixe a la somme de L.E. 737.500 represente par 1o)50.000 actions ordinaries de L.E. 5 chacune. 2o) 100.000 actions privilegiees Amortissables de (euro)5 chacune qui seront successivement remises entierement liberees, aux porteurs des actions ordinaries au prorara du nombre d'actions possedees par eux et en vertu de deliberation de l'assemblee generale des actionnaires en representation de benefices acquis sur les reventes de la societe.
ARTICLE 7 (1er paragraphe)
Texte Actuel
Chaque action donne droit dans la propriete de l'aetif social et dans le partage du benefice a une part proportion-nelle au nombre des actions emises.
Texte Propose

Chaque action ordinaire donne droit dans la propriete de l'actif social et dans le partage des benefices a une part proportionnelle au nombre d'actions emises. Les actions privilegiees n'ont droit qu'a un interet de 5% l'an cumulatif et au pair et a titre privilegie de leur valeur nominale par voie d'amortissement en vertu du tirage au sort.
Article 38 (premier paragraphe)
Texte Actuel

Sur les benefices nets de l'exercise social apres deduction de tous frais et charges de la societe, il sera preleve d'abord la somme necessaire pour fournir un interet de 5% sur le capital nominale des actions.
Texte Purpose

Sur les benefices nets de l'exercise social apres deduction de tous frais et charges de la cociete il sera preleve d'abord la somme necessaire pour fournir de 5% d'interet prevu a l'article 7 des statuts au nombre d'actions privilegiees, dont l'assemblee generale aura autorise la distribution proportionnelle aux actionnaires. Ensuite il sera preleve la somme necessaire pour fournir un interet de 5% sur le capital nominal des actions ordinaires.
Pour le surplus le texte actuel des trois articles précités est maintenu.

Tout poiteur de vingt notions a droit d’assister à l’Assemblée Générale, mais conformément à l’Article 24 des Statuts, il devra justifier auprès de la Société du dépôt de ses Actions un jour avant la date fixée . pour la réunion. II est rappelé qu’aux termes de l’article 30 des statuts il ne pourra être délibéré valablement sur les objets portés à l’ordre du jour, de l’assemblée générale extraordinaire qu’au tant que les aotions représentées formeront an moins la moitié du capital. L’Administrateur-Directeur, (Signé) E. W. P. Foster. Alexandrie, le 16 février 1905. 25447-4*-3

div.head: National Bank of Egypt.
div.p: AVIS

Messieurs les Actionnaires de la National Bank of Egypt sont convoqués eu Assemblée Générale Ordinaire pour le Lundi vingt Mars 1905, à trois heures et demie de l’après-midi, au Siège Social, au Caire.
ORDRE DU JOUR :

Rapport du Conseil d’Administration. Rapport des Censeurs. Approbation des Comptes de l’exercice clos le 31 Décembre 1904. Fixation du dividende. Renouvellement partiel du Conseil d’Administration. Election des Censeurs pour l’exercice 1905. Fixation de l’indemnité des Censeurs.

Tout actionnaire possédant au moins vingt actions a droit de prendre part à l’Assemblée Générale à oôndition de déposer ses actions dans lieux ci-après désignés où il lui sera delivre une carte d'admission.
En Egypte : Cinq jonre au moins avant le jour de la réunion, soit le 15 Mare an pins tard :

au Siège Social, au Caire, à la Succursale d’Alexandrie, aux Agences de la Banque à Assiout, Assouan, Benha, Beni-Souef, Chibin-El-Kom, Damanhour, Fayum, Keneh, Man-sourah, Minieh, Port-Saïd, Sohag, Tantah, Zagazig et Musky (Caire).
à l’Anglo-Egyptian Bank, a la banque Imper. Ott., au Crédit Lyonnais, à la Bank of Egypt.
au Caire ou à Alexandrie.

En Europe, au plus tard le 10 mars : à Paris et à Marseille, aux bureaux de la “Société Marseillaise”, en Italie, dans les bureaux de la “Banca Commerciale Italiana”, à Bank of Egypt, 4 et 5 King William Street.
Le Gouverneur: Elwin Palmer.
Le Caire, le 18 Fevrier 1905. 25456-10-*4

div.head: Agricultural Bank of Egypt.
div.p: ORDINARY SHARES.

Holders of the above are hereby informed that a dividend at the rate of six shillings (6/-) per share has been declared for the year 1904 payable on and after 1st March 1905, against delivery of coupon No. 2.—These coupons will be paid by the National Bank of Egypt, Cairo, Alexandria, and also at their Agency in London, 4 and 5, King William Street.

Registered shareholders are requested to lodge their Certificates for verification and further registration at the Offices of the National Bank of Egypt when a Dividend Warrant will be handed to them,.
DEFERRED SHARES.
A dividend at the rate of £6.3.0. per share has also been declared payable on these shares against delivery of coupon No. 1. National Bank of Egypt Cairo, 22nd February 1905. 25480-7-6

div.head: Municipalité d’Alexandrie
div.p: AVIS
La Municipalité procédera le 4 Avril prochain à l’adjudication pour la fourniture d’un rouleau compresseur à vapeur.
Le cautionnement est fixé à L.E.100.
L’offre devra indiquer le type du rouleau offert, son poids en ordre de marche, le délai maximum pour la livraison, ainsi que tous autres renseignements qui s’y réfèrent.
Le montage est à la charge de l’adjudicataire et la consignation sera faite libre de tous frais au Dépôt de la Voirie sis à la rue du 1er Khédive.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l’Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 4 Avril prochain.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5h.p.m.
L’enveloppe devra en outre porter la mention: “Soumission pour la fourniture d’un rouleau compresseur.”
Le cautionnement ou le reçu d’une banque devra être remis au Service de la Comptabilité avant l’ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 4 Avril à midi.
L’Administrateur, (Signé) W. P. Chataway Alexandrie le 25 février 1905. 25,503-3-3
AVIS
La Municipalité met en adjudication l’impression des procès-verbaux des séances de la Commission, de la Délégation et antres imprimés en arabe pour la durée de trois ans à partir du 1er Avril 1905.
Le cautionnement est fixé à L.E. 15.
Le cahier des charges est déposé an bureau de la Comptabilité Générale où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l’Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 14 Mars 1905.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5h.p.m.
L’enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention : “Soumission pour impression arabe des procès-verbaux de la Délégation, Commission et autres”.
Le cautionnement ou le reçu d’une Banque, d’après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis à la Comptabilité Générale avant l’ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 14 mars à midi.
L’Administrateur, (Signé) W. P. Chataway Alexandrie, le 25 février 1905. 25497-3-3

div.head: EGYPTIAN DELTA LAND & INVESTMENT COMPANY LIMITED.
div.p: NOTICE is hereby given to holders of Shares in the above Company that a fresh issue of Capital is shortly to be made to Shareholders. New shares can only be allotted to persons whose names are registered in the Company’s Books in London at the date of issue or to holders of Bearer Warrants. Holders of nominative certificates in names other than their own who wish to participate in the new issue should therefore forward their nominative certificates with transfer deeds duly executed to the National Bank of Egypt, Cairo or Alexandria, not later than 24th March 1905.
By order of the Board, A. Adams, Managing Director. Cairo, 24th February 1905. 25490 6-5
